Module contents¶

class pymerkle.merkle_tree(*records, hash_type='sha256', encoding='utf-8', security=True, log_dir='/home/beast/projects/pymerkle/docs')[source]¶

Bases: object

Class for Merkle-Trees

Parameters:
  • hash_type (str) – [optional] Defaults to ‘sha256’. Should be included in hashing.HASH_TYPES (upper- or mixed-case with ‘-‘ instead of ‘_’ allowed), otherwise an exception is thrown.
  • encoding (str) – [optional] Defaults to ‘utf_8’. Should be included in hashing.ENCODINGS (upper- or mixed-case with ‘-‘ instead of ‘_’ allowed), otherwise an exception is thrown.
  • security (bool) – [optional] Defaults to True. Activates defense against second-preimage attack (genuinely activated only for the default values of hash and encoding types)
  • *records (str or bytes or bytearray) – [optional] The records initially stored by the Merkle-Tree; usually empty at construction. If given, the is constructed with as many leafs from the beginning, storing the hashes of the inserted records in the respective order.
  • log_dir (str) – [optional] Absolute path of the directory, where the Merkle-Tree will receive log files to encrypt from. Defaults to the current working directory if unspecified
Variables:
  • uuid – (str) uuid of the Merkle-Tree (time-based)
  • hash_type – (str) Type of hashing algorithm used by the Merkle-Tree
  • encoding – (str) Encoding type used by the Merkle-Tree for encryption
  • security – (bool) Iff True, security measures against second-preimage attack are activated
  • hash – (method) Core hash functionality of the Merkle-Tree.
  • multi_hash – (method) Hash functionality used by the Merkle-Tree for performing inclusion test upon a request for consistency proof.
  • log_dir – (bool) See homonymous argument of the constructor
JSONstring()[source]¶

Returns a nicely stringified version of the Merkle-Tree’s JSON serialized form

Note

The output of this function is to be passed in the print() function

Return type:str
audit_path(index)[source]¶

Computes and returns the body for the audit-proof based upon the requested index.

Body of an audit-proof consist of an audit-path (a sequence of signed hashes) and a proof-index (the position within the above sequence where the validation procedure should start from).

Parameters:index (int) – index of the leaf where the audit-proof calculation should be based upon (provided from Client’s Side directly or indirectly in form of a record; cf. the .audit_proof method).
Returns:a tuple of signed hashes (pairs of the form (+1/-1, str)), the sign +1 or -1 indicating pairing with the right or left neighbour during proof validation respectively, along with the starting point for application of hashing during proof validation.
Return type:(int, tuple)

Note

If the requested index is either negative or exceeds the tree’s current length (IndexError), then the nonsensical tuple (None, None) is returned.

audit_proof(arg)[source]¶

Response of the Merkle-Tree to the request of providing an audit-proof based upon the given argument.

Parameters:arg (str or bytes or bytearray or int) – the record (if type is str or bytes or bytearray) or index of leaf (if type is int) where the proof calculation must be based upon (provided from Client’s Side)
Returns:Audit proof appropriately formatted along with its validation parameters (so that it can be passed in as the second argument to the validations.validate_proof method)
Return type:proof.proof
clear()[source]¶

Deletes all nodes of the Merkle-Tree

consistency_path(sublength)[source]¶

Computes and returns the body for any consistency-proof based upon the requested sublength.

Parameters:sublength (int) – length (number of leaves) for a presumably valid previous stage of the Merkle-Tree
Returns:the starting point for application of hashing during proof validation, a tuple of hashes signed with - (leftmost hashes for inclusion test to be performed from the Server’s Side, i.e., by the Merkle-Tree itself) and a tuple of signed hashes for top-hash test to be performed from the Client’s Side (the sign +1, resp. -1 indicating pairing with the right or left neigbour respectively during proof validation).
Return type:(int, tuple, tuple)

Note

Returns None for sublength equal to 0

consistency_proof(old_hash, sublength)[source]¶

Response of the Merkle-Tree to the request of providing a consistency-proof for the given parameters.

Arguments of this function amount to a presumed previous stage of the Merkle-Tree (root-hash and length respectively) provided from Client’s Side.

Parameters:
  • old_hash (str or bytes or bytearray or int) – root-hash of a presumably valid previous stage of the Merkle-Tree
  • sublength (int) – presumable length (number of leaves) for the above previous stage of the Merkle-Tree
Returns:

Consistency proof appropriately formatted along with its validation parameters (so that it it can be passed in as the second argument to the validations.validate_proof method)
Return type:

proof.proof
display(indent=3)[source]¶

Prints the Merkle-Tree in a terminal friendy way

Printing the tree is similar to what is printed at console when running the tree command of Unix based platforms.

Parameters:indent (int) – [optional] The horizontal depth at which each level will be indented with respect to its previous one. Defaults to 3.
encrypt_log(log_file)[source]¶

Encrypts the data of the provided log-file into the Merkle-Tree.

More accurately, it successively updates the Merkle-Tree it with each line of the log-file provided (cf. doc of the .update method)

Parameters:log_file (str) – relative path of the log-file under enryption, specified with respect to the Merkle-Tree’s directory log_dir
height()[source]¶

Calculates and returns the Merkle-Tree’s current height

Since the tree is by construction binary balanced, its height coincides with the length of its leftmost branch.

Return type:int
length()[source]¶

Returns the Merkle-Tree’s current length (i.e., the nuber of its leaves)

Return type:int
minimal_complement(subroots)[source]¶

Complements optimally the subroot hashes detected by .principal_subroots with all necessary interior hashes of the Merkle-Tree, so that a full consistency-path cN be generated

Parameters:subroots (list of nodes.node) – Should be some output of the .principal_subroots method
Returns:a list of signed hashes complementing optimally the hashes detected by .principal_subroots, so that a full consistency-path be generated
Return type:list of signed pairs (+1/-1, str)
principal_subroots(sublength)[source]¶

Detects and returns in corresponding order the roots of the successive, rightmost, full binary subtrees of maximum (and thus decreasing) length, whose lengths sum up to the inserted argument.

Returned nodes are prepended with a sign (+1 or -1), carrying information used in consistency-proof generation after extracting hashes.

Parameters:sublength (int) –

Should be an integer satisfying the following compatibility condition: if the Merkle-Tree’s current length decomposes additively as

2 ^ (p_1) + ... + 2 ^ (p_m), p_1 > ... > p_m >= 0

in decreasing powers of 2, then sublength is of the form

2 ^ (p_1) + ... + 2 ^ (p_n)

for some 1 <= n <= m.
Returns:The (signed) roots of the detected subtrees, whose hashes are to be used for the generation of consistency-proofs
Return type:list of (+1/-1, nodes.node)

Note

Returns None in case of incompatibility, i.e., if the provided sublength does not fulfill the required condition

root_hash()[source]¶

Returns current top-hash of the Merkle-Tree,i.e., the hash stored by its current root

Returns:The tree’s current root hash in hexadecimal form
Return type:str
serialize()[source]¶

Returns a JSON structure with the Merkle-Trees’s current characteristics as key-value pairs

Return type:dict

Note

This method does not serialize the tree structure itself, but only the info about the tree’s fixed configurations (hash type, encoding type, security mode, uuid) and current state (size, length, height, root-hash).

size()[source]¶

Returns the current number of the Merkle-Tree’s nodes

Return type:int
subroot(start, height)[source]¶

Returns the root of the unique full binary subtree of the Merkle-Tree, whose leftmost leaf is located at the given position start and whose height is equal to the given height.

Parameters:
  • start (int) – index of leaf where detection of subtree should start from
  • height (int) – height of candidate subtree to be detected
Returns:

root of the detected subtree
Return type:

nodes.node

Note

Returns None if the requested start is out of range

update(record)[source]¶

Updates the Merkle-Tree by storing the hash of the inserted record in a newly created leaf, restructuring the tree appropriately and recalculating all necessary interior hashes

Parameters:record (str or bytes or bytearray) – the record whose hash is to be stored in a new leaf
pymerkle.validate_proof(target_hash, proof)[source]¶

Core validation function

Validates the inserted proof by comparing to the provided target hash, modifies the proof’s status as True or False according to validation result and returns this result.

Parameters:
  • target_hash (str) – hash (hexadecimal form) to be presumably attained at the end of the validation procedure (i.e., acclaimed top-hash of the Merkle-Tree having provided the proof)
  • proof (proof.proof) – the proof to be validated
Returns:

validation result
Return type:

bool
class pymerkle.proof_validator(validations_dir=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Wrapper of the validate_proof function.

Employs the validation_receipt class in order to organize validation results in an easy storable way.

Parameters:validations_dir (str) – [optional] absolute path of the directory where validation receipts will be stored as .json files. Defaults to None, in which case validation receipts will not be automatically stored.
validate(target_hash, proof)[source]¶

Wraps validate_proof, returning a validation receipt instead of a boolean.

If a validations_dir has been specified at construction, then the produced validation receipt is automatically stored in that directory as a .json file named with the receipt’s uuid.

Parameters:
  • target_hash (str) – hash (hexadecimal form) to be presumably attained at the end of the validation procedure (i.e., acclaimed top-hash of the Merkle-Tree having provided the proof)
  • proof (proof.proof) – the proof to be validated
Return type:

validations.validation_receipt
